Award.AwardTitle: CiC (SEA): Large Scale Prediction of Transcription Factor Binding Sites for Gene Regulation Using Cloud Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the development of sequencing technologies, over 1,400 bacterial genomes have been sequenced and this number is rising exponentially. To understand these organisms, we first need to identify all the functional sequences in the genomes. Although tremendous advances have been made in computational prediction of gene-coding sequences in genomes, our ability to accurately predict another type of important functional sequences--transcription factor binding sites (TFBSs) is still very limited due to the notorious difficulty of the problem. In this project, researchers will develop accurate algorithms and tools for predicting TFBSs in genomes at a large scale using a graph-theoretic approach. The algorithms will then be parallelized and adapted to the Microsoft Azure cloud platform to predict TFBSs in thousands of sequenced bacterial genomes.

Since it remains an unsolved task to efficiently and accurately predict TFBSs in all sequenced bacterial genomes, the algorithms, tools and predictions resulted from this project will greatly aid in deciphering gene regulatory networks in sequenced bacterial genomes. This will directly impact our ability to understand bacteria and utilize them for various purposes, and thus provide the foundations for new strategies for renewable energy production, environment protection, and infectious disease prevention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gene transcriptional regulation plays a crucial role in almost all aspects of bacterial life. The research from this project has provided computational tool for studying gene transcriptional regulation in bacteria: 1) a new transcription factor binding site similarity measure SPIC, which is more accurate than the prior state-of-the-art methods to catch the subtle differences in binding sites;?2) a new motif-finding algorithm and tool MotifClick, which balances the prediction specificity and sensitivity well; 3) an parallel algorithm and tool eGLECLUBS for local computer clusters and Windows Azure Cloud Computing Platform for efficient prediction of transcription?factor binding sites in a group of bacterial genomes; 4) an algorithm?and tool TRuHMM for assembling full-length transcripts in bacteria using next-generation transcriptome sequencing technologies; and 5) a database for predicted operons and transcription factor binding sites in sequenced bacterial genomes for the research community to use. Furthermore, the researchers found that E. coli K12 has far more complex transcriptomes in responses to environmental changes than previously thought. In addition, a postdoctoral fellow, and several graduate, undergraduate and high school students were trained throughout the project. Thus, the project not only has broader impacts on all levels of education in the institution, but also has largely advanced the motif finding research and will greatly facilitate the elucidation of gene transcriptional regulation networks in bacteria. A better understanding of bacteria has great significance in global ecological control, efficient agriculture, better medicine and health, and renewal energy production.
